sections.name: Coal Ash
content: Coal ash is the byproduct of burning coal, including fly ash, bottom ash, boiler slag, and flue gas desulfurization material [coal_ash_basics]. Coal ash contains harmful materials, such as arsenic, cadmium, and mercury, and it can cause water and air pollution [coal_ash_basics]. Burning one ton of coal produces about 0.15 tons of ash [coal_ash_amt].

Following spills at Kingston, Tennessee, where at least 30 clean-up workers have died from illnesses suspected to be linked to the spill [nrdc_kingston], and at Eden, North Carolina [eden_spill], the U. S. EPA has instituted regulations on coal ash disposal. The rules requires liners to control water pollution and other safeguards, but it may be inadequate [ash_rule].
